## Three Wave Panel

```{tikz engine.opts=font_opts}
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=2.0, transform shape]
\node [draw = none, inner sep = 0] (U) at (0, 0) {$U$};
\node [rectangle, draw=black,align=left] (L) at (2, 0) {\footnotesize $L_{0}$\\\footnotesize
$A_{0}$\\ \footnotesize $Y_{0}$};
\node [draw = none, inner sep = 0] (A) at (4, 0) {$A_1$};
\node [draw = none, inner sep = 0] (Y) at (6,0) {$Y_2$};
\draw [-latex] (U) -- (L);
\draw [-latex, bend left=80, dotted] (U) to  node[pos=0.55, above] {\tiny orthogonal confounding}(A);
\draw [-latex, bend right=80, dotted] (U) to node[pos=0.45, below] {\tiny orthogonal confounding} (Y);
\draw [-latex] (L) -- (A);
\draw [-latex,bend left=20] (L) to (Y);
\end{tikzpicture}
```

## Explanation

1. In the YAML header, we add `tikz-cd` to the `extra_dependencies` list. This tells R Markdown to include the tikz-cd package when compiling the document.

2. We use a LaTeX code chunk (```{=latex}) to insert raw LaTeX code into our R Markdown document.

3. Inside this chunk, we use the tikz-cd syntax to create our diagram.
